description: From Middle English frok, frokke, from Old French froc (“frock, a monk's gown or habit”), perhaps via Medieval Latin hrocus, roccus, rocus (“a coat”), from Frankish *hroc, *hrok (“skirt, dress, robe”), from Proto-Germanic *hrukkaz (“robe, jacket, skirt, tunic”), from Proto-Indo-European *kreḱ- (“to weave”).

Cognate with Old High German hroch, roch (“skirt, dress, cowl”) – whence German Rock (“skirt, coat”) –, Saterland Frisian Rok (“skirt”), Dutch rok (“skirt, petticoat”), Old English rocc (“an overgarment, tunic, rochet”), Old Norse rokkr (“skirt, jacket”), whence Danish rok (“garment”).

entries.meaning: A dress, a piece of clothing, which consists of a skirt and a cover for the upper body.
An outer garment worn by priests and other clericals; a habit.

verbs.description: frock (third-person singular simple present frocks, present participle frocking, simple past and past participle frocked)

examples: […]  Mrs. Parmly-Coles, in thus frocking her daughter, was no jealous cat but a pearl among mothers.

entries.meaning: (US military, transitive) To grant to an officer the title and uniform of a rank he will soon be promoted to.
examples: MajGen Richard G. Schulze  […]  was selected for two-star rank by members of the January selection board. He was frocked on 27 Jan and assigned new duties as CG, MCRD, San Diego.

description: From Middle English froke, variation of frogge (“frog”), from Old English frocga (“frog”). More at frog.
